div.p: In respect to your debt to Moses please to leave it alone till he has finished your work. This He will do on the terms he gave in: but will not work so cheap for any one else for he finds he cannot well afford: but of this be silent.

The Print of Mowbray
Thomas Mowbray (I), first duke of Norfolk (1366–1399). Pennant quotes the accounts of Froissart and Holinshed of the dispute between Mowbray and Henry Bolingbroke (later Henry IV) at some length in The journey from Chester to London (1782), pp. 166–173, and includes a plate entitled 'The Challenge between the Duke of Hereford and Thomas Mowbray duke of Norfolk, taken from the beautiful MS. of Froissart, in the Harleian library, marked 4380', Plate IX at p. 167minus. ODNB. is completed. as are some others. Mr Bartollozi has had near an year & a quarter the fine drawings of
Margt
Margaret Countess of Cumberland
Margaret Clifford [née Russell], countess of Cumberland (1560–1616). Portrait(s) in oils, 1585, are found at Gorhambury, Hertfordshire. ODNB. See The Journey from Chester to London, p. 246–7, for Pennant's account of Margaret Russell, and Plate XIII at p. 246+, for her portrait, entitled 'Margaret Countess of Cumberland'. The
Countess of Suffolk
Katherine Howard [nee Knyvett; other married name Rich], countess of Suffolk (b. in or after 1564, d. 1630). ODNB. Pennant includes the 'fine full-length' portrait of Katherine Howard (whom he describes as having 'a great ascendancy over her husband' and as 'extremely rapacious') at Gorhambury, in The journey from Chester to London, pp. 227–8, Plate XI at p. 228+. The original oil on canvass drawing, dated 1620 and attributed to Sir Nathaniel Bacon, is still at Gorhambury. Ex inf. Jane O'Grady, Gorhambury Estates Co. both taken from the originals at Gorhambury.Old Gorhambury, near St Albans, Hertfordshire, built during the sixteenth century, was replaced by Gorhambury House by 1784. When Pennant visited it in 1780 it was 'unhappily devoted to demolition'. The journey from Chester to London, p. 233. He was to have finished them by too morrow; but will not now even answer my letters. He has a house in Bentinck court Berwick but usually lives at North end Hammersmith:Bartolozzi took a house at North End, Fulham, in 1780. if can possibly get a sight of him, you will do me & yourself a service for they the heads are rare subjects.

You ought to have a sheet of Letter press with Moses’s ten plates. For the ten supplemental plates to A Journey to Snowdon, see NLW 12710C, where they are bound at the end of the volume; and NLW 12711C, which also includes nine out of the ten bound at the end. LINK TO WORKS LIST: A Journey to Snowdon (London: Henry Hughes: 1781) I believe I have a L. P. set of the prints for you: but not letter press.
I am in high spirits about our affairs. The wisdom of our administration appears to me daily more or more or we never could have resisted the whole world so long.
our best wishes attend your & yours,
